title: What Is a Pilar Cyst (Trichilemmal Cyst​) on the Scalp?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributor, Felicia Wilson

content: A pilar cyst, sometimes called a trichilemmal cyst , forms when a hair follicle gets clogged. They can happen anywhere on your body but are most common on the scalp. Pilar cysts can be irritating but are usually not dangerous to your health.

sections.heading: What Causes a Pilar Cyst?
content: Pilar cysts of the scalp are slow-growing, painless cysts . They form in blocked hair follicles and get larger with time. Since you have hair follicles all over your body, you may also find pilar cysts on your face, neck, chest, stomach, and back. They are more common on the scalp because of the oils your scalp secretes to nourish hair.
Pilar or trichilemmal cysts usually appear on your scalp. They are harmless and noncancerous. Photo Credit: iStock/Getty Images

Pilar cysts begin when the outer layer of skin, the epidermis, sheds old skin cells. These shedding cells can sometimes shift under the surface of your skin instead of falling off. When this happens, the shedded cells start multiplying as if they are still growing. Instead of moving up to the surface, they stay trapped under your skin and begin to build up.‌

Meanwhile, your scalp produces keratin, a protein that helps maintain hair health. The keratin also builds up with the dead skin cells under your epidermis. This is the white-yellow liquid that you may see oozing from your cyst if it ruptures.

sections.heading: How Does a Pilar Cyst Feel on the Scalp​?
content: Pilar cysts on the scalp look and feel like smooth, firm lumps. They are skin-colored and filled with keratin, a protein found in your hair, skin, and nails. Most people develop more than one of these cysts on their scalp.
They start as small bumps and can grow to be larger – sometimes as big as a baseball.

sections.heading: How Are Pilar Cysts Diagnosed?
content: Pilar cysts can sometimes be diagnosed by your doctor with a simple visual examination. However, pilar cysts can look like other skin conditions , so your doctor will need to rule out other health concerns. They will ask you questions about your symptoms and, if necessary, may take a biopsy of the pilar cyst to look at under a microscope.
Pilar cysts and sebaceous cysts may seem similar, but they aren’t. Here are some key differences.
Pilar cysts:
Sebaceous cysts:
bullets: Usually found on your scalp
Round in shape
Made up of keratin
Can appear anywhere on your body,
Often dome-shaped with a hole
Contain sebum, a waxy substance created by your sebaceous glands

sections.heading: How to Treat Pilar Cysts on the Scalp
content: Self-healing. A pilar cyst on your scalp may go away on its own over time. Keep in mind that just as the cyst is slow-growing, it is also slow to shrink back down. This is especially true if it is large and contains a lot of fluid that needs to drain out.
If you don’t want to wait and see if the pilar cyst on your scalp shrinks, you can talk to your doctor about more active treatment options.

Cyst removal. While generally not harmful, pilar cysts can be irritating and cause pain when brushing hair. Pilar cysts can be removed by your doctor with a simple outpatient surgery that involves cutting open the cyst, draining the fluid, and removing the cyst wall so it doesn’t return.

sections.heading: What Are the Complications of Pilar Cysts?
content: Pilar or trichilemmal cysts on your scalp can cause problems if they rupture and become infected. If this happens, bacteria may enter your bloodstream through the wound opening and cause other symptoms similar to an illness. Infections may require a topical or oral antibiotic and can become serious without medical attention. Signs that your pilar cyst is infected include:
bullets: Pain in or around the cyst
Thick fluid oozing from the cyst
A bad smell coming from the oozing liquid‌
Inflammation, redness, or swelling‌

content: If you have any of these symptoms, talk to your doctor right away.
To prevent infection and potential scarring , avoid:
Warm compresses, such as warm wash cloths, may help the cyst drain on its own over time.
bullets: Squeezing the cyst
Trying to “pop” it and drain the liquid
Sticking a needle in it
Cutting it open by yourself to remove the cyst

sections.heading: How to Prevent Pilar Cysts
content: Doctors have not identified a way to prevent cysts from forming. There isn’t a way to predict when or where a pilar cyst of the scalp may form.
Pilar or trichilemmal cysts are hereditary. You are likely to develop these if others in your family have them.

However, pilar or cysts on the scalp are not cancerous and usually don’t have negative effects on your overall health. While most pilar cysts are painless, some cysts may be irritated if you bump or scratch them. Being located on your scalp, it is easy to brush or comb your pilar cyst without realizing it.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Pilar or trichilemmal cysts are harmless, slow-growing lumps that commonly appear on your scalp due to blocked hair follicles.
They're filled with keratin, not oil, which makes them feel firm and smooth.

While they often go away on their own, they can become irritated or infected if bumped or ruptured. If a cyst becomes painful, or there’s swelling, redness, or foul-smelling discharge , see your doctor.

sections.heading: Pilar Cyst FAQs
content: Yes. Pilar cysts or trichilemmal cysts are the most common type of skin cysts. About 10% of the population gets them. They are noncancerous and harmless.
Pilar cysts are usually noncancerous. They form around hair follicles. In very rare cases, a pilar cyst could become malignant, also known as a proliferating trichilemmal tumor.
No. Pilar cysts are usually noncancerous and harmless. They can grow to be as large as a baseball and cause some pain and irritation.

To prevent infection or possible scarring, see your doctor to remove a pilar cyst. Don’t try to pop it, stick a needle in it, squeeze it, or cut it open yourself. You can try to use warm compresses to help it drain on its own.
